instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> VCore in and out
threads.message:
This board came in with minor liquid damage around <CHIP>U1900</CHIP>, <CHIP>U6100</CHIP>. Broken trace from pin 1 <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> to <RESISTOR>R6117</RESISTOR> repaired. Board now turns on and boots but seems when I flex or put pressure around L7320 area (not saying it is L7320) Vcore shuts down (1.7V to 0) PPBUS stays steady 8.5 as well as <SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING</SIGNAL>. This area was not exposed to liquid. This happens with or without I/O cable connected. 

Thanks, have a good one.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> VCore in and out
threads.message: Pfff, I bet it was messed with and somehow now its got cracked ball/trace under the CPU. You can do a reflow of the CPU Vcore regulator area, but it may just mask the problem for a few days/weeks. Expect a return and a no fix.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> VCore in and out
threads.message:
Reflowed that area. It seemed to work so I installed it out of curiosity. Now it stays on as long as I dont jostle it or turn the computer upside down... Whats odd is that the board is screwed down. I dont know how flipping it upside down while in the machine would make difference. Lol,  this started out as such an easy board to fix too! FML.
Thanks Duke.
